texts.shortText: This species has only 10 rather slender arms that are held curved over the body. On the upper surface of the body the ambulacral grooves converge on the mouth, which is situated centrally, whereas the anus (situated on a conical process) occupies an off-centre position. On the underside there 35-40 fairly-slender attachment cirri. Colour is extremely variable, but most commonly brownish-yellow, sometimes with striped pinnules.

Global: Endemic to South Africa.

Local/Regional: Saldanha Bay to Durban.

Found in low intertidal pools and under rocks and overhangs, but most abundant on shallow reefs to a depth af about 26 m, where it can occur in the open in dense and extensive beds, often mixed with the similar-looking Common feather-star Comanthus wahlbergii, with which it is often confused (see below). Like most feather stars capable of swimming using a slow, graceful up and down movement of the arms if displaced from the reef. As the group name suggests, the arms are brittle and easily broken, but are quickly regenerated. Individuals with some shorter arms, or a reduced number of arms, are thus regularly encountered.

The arms are extended upwards into the water column to intercept floating plankton of other organic particles. Each pinnule is lined with tubefeet, which are held erect to form a mesh.  The tubefeet grasp passing particles and pass them to an ambulacral groove running along the length of the arm, along which cilia propel a string of mucus and food particles to the mouth, which is situated on the upper surface of the central disc. A fairly simple U-shaped gut fills most of the small body and ends in an anus that is raised on a cone close to the mouth and also on the upper surface.

Details unknown for this species, but sexes separate and the gonads are located in the swollen basal pinnules, rather than in the small body itself. When the gametes are mature the pinnules rupture and release the eggs and sperm into the water column, where they develop as planktonic larvae before settling back onto suitable substrata. Newly settled larvae are stalked (like many fossil crinoids), but the stalk is lost as they enter the adult stage.

Easily confused with the Common feather-star Comanthus wahlbergii but usually has fewer arms (10 vs 10-22 but usually 16-20). That species has the mouth off-centre and the anal cone in the centre of the upper body surface. The two species are most easily distinguished by the markedly different number of ventral cirri, which number 12-25 in C. wahlbertii, but 35-40 in A. occidentalis. In practice though, very few photographers turn specimens over and count their cirri, so the identity of species in many published images is suspect! It would be a valuable study to compare the distribution patterns of these two species and to determine their relative abundances, size ranges and habitat preferences (and to record the range and proportions of various arm numbers and colour forms in each species).

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2022). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 228).

Clark, AM & Courtman-Stock, J (1976). The Echinoderms of Southern Africa. British Museum (Natural History), London (p. 20).
